headline.main: WELLES IS DELEGATE TO AMERICAS' PARLEY; Conference at Panama Will Deal With Security in War

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: NO war of magnitude during the past century has been fought without new postal paper resulting, and the  struggle now in progress in Europe is not expected by philatelists to prove an exception.
docs.lead_paragraph: NO war of magnitude during the past century has been fought without new postal paper resulting, and the struggle now in progress in Europe is not expected by philatelists to prove an exception.

headline.main: WAR NOTED IN STAMPS; 1914 Experience Leads To Expectation of Postal Changes Colonial War Stamps Stamp Prices Decline Some Advances
PROGAMS OF THE WEEK; Musicologists to Hold Meetings and Give Concerts--Brooklyn Opera
SHIPPING AND MAILS; DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME

docs.snippet: Despite the fear that the European war might mean many cancellations, the first international congress of the American Musicological Society opened here yesterday with nearly a full complement of delegates and guests. Only two guests, one from France...
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the fear that the European war might mean many cancellations, the first international congress of the American Musicological Society opened here yesterday with nearly a full complement of delegates and guests. Only two guests, one from France and one from Germany, did not appear.

headline.main: CONGRESS OF MUSIC OPENS DESPITE WAR; Only the French and German Delegates Fail to Attend First Session Here ART HELD LINK FOR PEACE Musicologists' Gathering Puts Emphasis on Preservation of World Scholarship

docs.snippet: German submarines, which played so decisive a part in the World War, continued their relentless attack on British merchant shipping yesterday, sending four freighters of 19,712 gross tons to the bottom. Their loss brought the toll of allied shipping...
docs.lead_paragraph: German submarines, which played so decisive a part in the World War, continued their relentless attack on British merchant shipping yesterday, sending four freighters of 19,712 gross tons to the bottom. Their loss brought the toll of allied shipping since Sept. 3--start of the war--to 16 vessels.

headline.main: REICH SUBMARINES SINK 4 MORE SHIPS; RESCUE SHIP CAPTAINS
SHIPPING AND MAILS; DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME

docs.snippet: Sharp criticism of marine insurance companies for their refusal to give war risk insurance coverage against the danger of seizure or capture of cargoes by Allied forces enlivened a meeting of export managers yesterday at which problems created by...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sharp criticism of marine insurance companies for their refusal to give war risk insurance coverage against the danger of seizure or capture of cargoes by Allied forces enlivened a meeting of export managers yesterday at which problems created by war-time conditions were discussed by foreign traders.

headline.main: EXPORTERS ATTACK WAR-RISK REFUSAL; Denial of Seizure Coverage Puts Them in Impossible Position, Traders Say UNDERWRITERS DEFENDED Broker Sees Shippers Here as No Worse Off Than Those in Other Countries

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Aviation experts said today that the war in Europe had left the United States alone in air transportation and, aircraft sales to Latin America.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Aviation experts said today that the war in Europe had left the United States alone in air transportation and, aircraft sales to Latin America.

headline.main: AIRLINES ABROAD QUIT LATIN AMERICA; War Leaves United States Alone in Flights and Sales of Planes to That Area ARGENTINA DIVERTS MAIL Pan American Gets EuropeBound Letters--CommerceProblems Are Raised
